raw_text:
Oil prices fall back from highs
 
 Oil prices retreated from four-month highs in early trading on Tuesday after producers' cartel Opec said it was now unlikely to cut production.
 
 Following the comments by acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin, US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel. He said that high oil prices meant Opec was unlikely to stick to its plan to cut output in the second quarter. In London, Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel.
 
 Opec members are next meeting to discuss production levels on 16 March. On Monday, oil prices rose for a sixth straight session, reaching a four-month high as cold weather in the US threatened stocks of heating oil. US demand for heating oil was predicted to be about 14% above normal this week, while stocks were currently about 7.5% below the levels of a year ago. Cold weather across Europe has also put upward pressure on crude prices.
llama3.2:1b: Oil prices fell from four-month highs as Opec said it's unlikely to cut production due to high prices. US light crude dropped by 32 cents to $51.43, while Brent crude dropped by 32 cents to $49.74 in London. Opec members are set to meet again on March 16.
llama3.2:3b: Oil prices fell from four-month highs after Opec said it was unlikely to cut production due to high oil prices. US light crude and Brent crude declined 32 cents, while stocks of heating oil were predicted to be above normal levels.
gemma2:2b: Oil prices fell back after reaching four-month highs due to Opec's decision not to cut production despite high prices.  Adnan Shihab-Eldin, acting Opec secretary general, stated that the cartel was unlikely to adhere to its planned output reduction in the second quarter.  This follows a six-session run of price increases fueled by cold weather in the US and Europe, which led to increased demand for heating oil.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Oil prices have dropped after producers' cartel Opec said it won't cut production. US light crude fell to $51.43 per barrel, and Brent crude lost 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel due to rising demand in Europe. Cold weather is expected to continue impacting oil prices, with heating oil stocks near record levels in the US and higher heating oil prices being predicted for Europe.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Oil prices fell back from four-month highs after OPEC reportedly unlikely to cut production in Q2. Prices rose again Monday following cold-weather-induced demand and supply concerns, reaching a four-month high.
qwen2.5:3b: Oil prices fell from four-month highs in early trading after Opec said it was unlikely to cut production. US light crude dropped by $0.32 to $51.43 per barrel, while Brent crude fell $0.32 to $49.74 per barrel. This follows a previous six-session rise due to cold weather affecting heating oil stocks and demand in the US. Opec's next production levels meeting is scheduled for March 16th.
opencoder:1.5b:
Oil prices have been falling back from highs since early trading on Tuesday following the comments by acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin.

Following the comments, US light crude oil fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel. The high oil prices meant that Opec was not likely to stick to its plan to cut output in the second quarter. In London, the crude oil fell more than expected due to cold weather and other factors.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is: Oil prices fell back from highs in early trading after producers' cartel Opec said it was no longer likely to cut production, and US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel. The comments by acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin meant that high oil prices meant Opec was unlikely to stick to its plan to cut output in the second quarter. In London Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel, and US Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel. The summary captures the main points of the text without any additional information or explanations.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text in plain text. The user provided some key points and wanted just the summary without explanations or extra formatting. Let me read through it carefully.

First, the main point is that oil prices fell from highs. Then Opec decided it's unlikely they'll cut production again. US and London prices dropped by 32 cents each. There was a sixth straight rise in US oil due to cold weather affecting heating oil demand. European colder weather also pushed crude prices up.

I should capture the main events: price drops, Opec's decision, US and London specifics, and global impacts from Europe.

Make sure to mention the date of the meeting (16 March) and the impact on prices before and after. Keep it concise without adding explanations.
</think>

Oil prices retreated below four-month highs after OPEC member states declared it unlikely they'd cut production again. In London, US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43, while Brent crude in London dropped 32 cents to $49.74. Opec's next meeting is on March 16. US demand for heating oil rose by 14% but stocks were down from a year ago. European colder weather lifted prices further.
tinyllama:1.1b: Oil prices have fallen back slightly from four-month highs following producer comments and forecasts indicating that production cuts by Opec are unlikely in the second quarter. Following Adnan Shihab-Eldin's remarks, US light crude fell 32 cent/barrel, while Brent crude dropped 32 cents to $51.43/barrel. Opce members will meet on March 16 to discuss production levels, with cold weather in the US threatening stockpiles of heat-reliant oil. Demand for heating oil is projected to be around 14% above normal this week, while stocks are currently about 7.5% below year-ago levels.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Oil prices dropped back from highs as concerns over oil production increased. Following comments made by acting OPEC secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin, the US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel. In London, global oil prices continued to rise. Oil prices are set to be discussed by OPEC members in their next meeting on 16 March. On Monday, oil prices rose for a sixth consecutive session due to cold weather across the US which is predicted to result in higher demand for heating oil and stocks of crude oil in the US being around 7.5% below last year's levels.
phi:2.7b: Oil prices declined from four-month highs after Opec expressed no intention of cutting production in response to high oil prices. This came as US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 and Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74, despite the US demand for heating oil being above normal due to cold weather conditions.
orca-mini:3b: Oil prices fell back from their highs after Opec said it was unlikely to cut production due to high prices. US light crude dropped 32 cents and Brent crude fell 32 cents, following comments by the acting Opec secretary general who said that high oil prices meant the group was unlikely to cut output. The next Opec meeting is on March 16th to discuss production levels.
hermes3:3b: Opec expects lower production, leading to oil prices falling from 4-month highs.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Oil prices retreated from four-month highs after OPEC indicated it is unlikely to cut production, due to high prices. US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel and Brent crude decreased by 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel. The next OPEC meeting will discuss production levels on 16 March.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Oil prices fell from four-month highs after Opec indicated it was unlikely to cut production. US light crude dropped 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel, while Brent crude fell to $49.74. Acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin cited high prices as a reason for maintaining output. Opec will meet on 16 March to discuss production levels. Previously, oil prices had risen for six consecutive sessions due to cold weather in the US and Europe, which increased demand for heating oil and pressured crude supplies.
stablelm2:1.6b: Oil prices fell back from four-month highs after OPEC said it wouldn't cut production, despite an acting OPEC secretary general's comments suggesting otherwise. US light crude and Brent crude both dropped 10 cents to $5 a barrel. OPEC members will discuss output levels in March following Monday's 6-session rise in oil prices to its highest level since February 2018. Factors contributing to the increase include cold weather threatening US heating oil stocks, which were currently about 7.5% below last year's levels; and cold weather across Europe increasing demand for crude.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Oil prices, which had reached four-month highs due to anticipated increased US demand for heating oil and cold weather in Europe, began to decline following OPEC's announcement that production cuts are unlikely for the second quarter. US light crude dropped 32 cents to $51.43 per barrel, while Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 per barrel in London. OPEC members will reassess production levels on March 16.
reference: Oil prices retreated from four-month highs in early trading on Tuesday after producers' cartel Opec said it was now unlikely to cut production.He said that high oil prices meant Opec was unlikely to stick to its plan to cut output in the second quarter.On Monday, oil prices rose for a sixth straight session, reaching a four-month high as cold weather in the US threatened stocks of heating oil.Following the comments by acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin, US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel.
